_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Automatic and manual emergency shutdowns; Routine maintenance and inspection.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: 24 hour manned surveillance / Mirrored surveillance at local 911 center
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All equipment critical to the process.
_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention program applies to all operations within the covered process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

EQUALIZER MIDWEST, INC.

HASTINGS, NEBRASKA





Equalizer Midwest, Inc. (a wholly-owned subsidiary of Equalizer, Inc.) owns and operates a fertilizer terminal facility near Hastings, Nebraska which is subject to the Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Program rule under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.  



The Risk Management Program rule requires a facility which handles threshold amounts of certain chemical substances to develop a program (if one is not already in existence) to prevent accidental releases of these substances and to minimize the consequences of those releases that do occur.  This Risk Management Program is to include a management system, a hazard assessment to identify the possible offsite impacts of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios, a five-year accident history record, an accidental release prevention program, an emergency response program and a Risk Management Plan which summarizes the entire program and is submitted to the EPA.



The following is the Executive Summary of the Risk Management Plan for this Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility located near Hastings in South Central Nebraska, serves as a storage and distribution terminal for fertilizer products.  



The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility serves as a vital link in the fertilizer distribution system by receiving products from manufacturing plants, by storing the products until they are needed and by distributing the products primarily in the Midwest region.  Being centrally located, the facility provides a convenient location for fertilizer retailers to get their product.  Additionally, Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is committed to being a solid, reliable member of the Hastings community.  



Equalizer Midwest, Inc. has 14 full-time employees, with a total of more than 100 years of combined operating experience.  This operating experience undoubtedly ad

ds to the safe operation and implementation of the Risk Management Plan and Process Safety Management programs.  



Anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility that is subject to the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule.  The anhydrous ammonia is primarily received by truck and shipped by truck and is stored as a refrigerated liquid at ambient pressure as well as a gas liquified by pressure.  A refrigeration system is utilized in support of the storage of the liquid at ambient pressure and various vessels and piping serve in the transfer of ammonia within the process.  The anhydrous ammonia distributed from this facility is used almost exclusively as an agricultural fertilizer.  Equalizer Midwest, Inc. does manufacture some liquid fertilizer using a stationary T-Reactor on site.  Anhydrous Ammonia is the only regulated substance in this process.



The facility was originally designed and constructed to be an anhydrous ammonia manufacturing plant and was operated as such from startup in 1962 until 1985, at which time the manufacturing process was discontinued.  Since 1985, the facility has functioned strictly as a storage and distribution terminal for anhydrous ammonia, utilizing the storage and transfer infrastructure of the original manufacturing plant.  Also, since 1985, changes including additions and improvements have resulted in the current design and operation of the terminal.  Farmland Industries, Inc. owned and operated the facility from 1962 until 2003.  In June of 2003, the facility was purchased by Equalizer, Inc. of Waco, Texas, which subsequently established the ownership and operation of the facility under Equalizer Midwest, Inc.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response 



It is the policy of Equalizer Midwest, Inc. to eliminate significant accidental releases of any substance and, particularly, of any hazardous or regulated substance and to minimize and eliminate to th

e extent possible even minor and inconsequential releases of any type.  Prevention of accidental releases is critical to the safe operation of the facility, to the safety of its employees and to the safety of the general public.  Consequently, the management and employees of the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases from this facility.



The Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility has a written Emergency Action Plan - as required by the RMProgram and other EPA and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules - and is committed to implement the plan in response to any accidental release to minimize the impact to employees, the community and the environment.  The action plan is coordinated with the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local emergency response agencies.   Personnel have interacted with these agencies for many years regarding activities at the facility and emergency response issues.  Equalizer Midwest is a non-responding facility, however, employees are trained to respond and deal with minor releases.





Prevention Program



As a handler of anhydrous ammonia in refrigerated storage, the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, 29CFR 1910.119, in addition to the RMProgram rule.  Under the RMProgram rule, the handling of ammonia at the facility is characterized as a Program 3 process, requiring a Program 3 Prevention Program.  For a facility with a Program 3 process, the Prevention Program required under the RMProgram rule is nearly identical to that required by the OSHA PSM standard.



The OSHA Process Safety Management/EPA RMP Prevention Program consists of a set of management policies and procedures which promotes and recognizes process safety and the prevention of accidents in facilities that handle, use, store and process hazardous substances.  The procedures address all aspects of facility activities including training, ma

intenance, operating procedures, process reviews, the maintenance and updating of critical process information, safe work practices, incident investigation, safety audits and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures and inadvertent changes in a process that could result in accidents. We continue to review and revise the programs and procedures of both OSHA's PSM and correspondingly EPA's RMProgram on an ongoing basis. 



Accidental Release Program



Specific features of the Accidental Release Prevention Program include personnel on-site 24 hr/day - 365 day/yr, visual inspection of process equipment as part of the daily routine, continuous monitoring of storage and transfer conditions, alarm systems to indicate operating conditions outside the norm, automatic shutdown of ammonia transfer when control parameters fall outside a specified range and manual remote shutdown of ammonia transfer - as needed, refrigeration system for ammonia storage, safety relief valves on all lines and vessels, flare in continuous operation, level indicators on all storage vessels, daily operating logs with inventory records, inspection program for all ammonia storage tanks, bullets, vessels and piping and monthly safety meetings.

Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is committed to adhering to and maintaining the Accidental Release Prevention Program.



Emergency Response Program



Equalizer Midwest, Inc. maintains an Emergency Action Plan and it is revised on an as needed basis by changes to the facility that may warrant modifications to the plan or by observed deficiencies in employee training.  The Plan is coordinated with the LEPC and is made available to the local emergency response agencies upon request.  Emergency Planning and Community Right-to Know information, as required under SARA Title III, has been provided to the Nebraska State Emergency Response Commission, the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the local jurisdictional fire depa

rtments.



Equalizer Midwest, Inc. is an active participant in the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee and interacts with various local agencies - such as fire departments, law enforcement departments and emergency medical providers - in its emergency planning.



Employees receive annual training in the facility's Emergency Action Plan and also receive various additional safety training, both in general and in the competencies relative to their required roles in the emergency action plan.



Five-year Accident History



The RMProgram rule requires inclusion of the five-year accident history of the facility for all accidental releases of regulated substances that resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



Equalizer Midwest Inc. has an excellent safety record at this facility, continuing a tradition began by the previous owner. We have not had any accidental releases of a regulated substance at this facility in the last five years.  There have been no injuries or off-site consequences dealing with the regulated substance in the last 5 years.



Planned Changes for Safety Improvements



Safety improvements occur as part of an ongoing evaluation process at the Equalizer Midwest, Inc. terminal and are facilitated by the Process Safety Management/Prevention Program.  In a formal procedure, at least every five years, the process hazard analysis is updated/revalidated, but review is also ongoing through management of change procedures, operator training, incident investigation and mechanical integrity programs.  As a result, changes relevant to safety occur continuously as needs are identified through these procedures and policies.
